text: Family Member 1: Monitored. Doctor: Yeah, monitored. And if it's the worst thing you've ever done, stop, start over on something else. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: If you feel fine, and you continue, then thumbs up. So it's a work in progress, really, for all of us. But I think if we just keep communicating, we'll do right by you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so my next step, honestly, is to get M____ in here so that we can just get the timing and things right and logistics. Family Member 1: So we're not starting nothing today. Doctor: No, because this isn't that you know, that oral pill is investigational. So you- the first thing we have to do is have you sign the right papers and make sure that whatever we just discussed, yep, get it get the copy at home, just so everybody's on the same page. Family Member 3: When does it start? Doctor: So we're hoping to start within a couple of weeks or but you know, or even sooner, because there’s that time crunch. Family Member 1: It worries me that, it’s aggressive, his cancer. Doctor: It is. It is. Family Member 1: So with him walking around, not on anything that is upsetting me.

text: Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And prostate’s the only one that this is true. Family Member: It’s the only one? text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: I wanted to have that conversation with you. Patient: Uh hum. Sure. And this is the PSA level; you’re also saying we need to see something on the CT scan, right? Doctor: Correct. So for this particular trial, if the cancer is invisible, which will become non-metastatic. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You would not be eligible. So it just has to do with; this trial is designed for a specific subset of patients so that cancer has to be both metastatic and hormone-resistant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So in other words invisible and resistant to hormone therapy, and then we basically do the screening procedures and if you pass the screening then we enroll you in the trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But again, I didn’t want to go into a huge amount of detail because it’s a little bit premature. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it would require also that you go back on the Lupron, which I’m not sure that you would want to do that. So just

text: Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: I was at 19. Doctor: You were 19 and you’re like at 42 I think Patient: Wow. Doctor: so that’s a hint that uh-oh something’s happening. So, we’ve got 2 options because I’m going to assume that your scans might show something is, maybe 1 or 2 new spots or something. Not drastically worse because you don’t look it. You don’t, that’s not how you are. Certainly, you’re better than the first time I met you. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, you’re in better shape, better control, but we have to get early, you know, we have to get an early jump on this. Let’s say the cancer is back or it’s worse. Well, you had that run of chemo so we’re not going to repeat that but other options would be, we actually have 3 studies to consider Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: but before I get to that let me just tell you what standard of care will be. One might be the vaccine trial which is basically getting your own blood cells to wake up and try to kill the cancer yourself because right now it’s kind of sleeping on the job Mr. S____. You have cancer and your immune cells are like ho-hum, nothing’s happening. It’s still letting the cancer do what it wants so that’s an FDA approved treatment. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: No cure but we have some long-term survival benefits so that’s one option. The other option is a different type of chemo so a cousin of the chemo that you had earlier this year. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: The third one is a pill um and it’s a like a super hormone pill that complements what’s going on with your Lupron injections that oh, you love so much. Those are standard of care like we have no studies going on at Karmanos. I could pick one off the shelf and we’d be good to go Patient: mm hmm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
